channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Cyprus: How did it all go wrong?
item.description: Cyprus has become the latest eurozone nation to apply for a bailout amidst a financial crisis linked to debt defaults in neighboring Greece. The Mediterranean island has a huge banking sector and its public debt is expected to match GDP within the next decade. Proposals to tax existing bank deposits as part of a rescue package have alarmed investors.

item.title: Quest: How to turn drama into crisis
item.description: Never underestimate the capacity of the Eurozone to shoot itself in both feet.

item.title: Russians to pull out of Cyprus?
item.description: CNN's Ratlisa Vassileva reports on fears of what will happen if Russians withdraw all their money.

item.title: The deal
item.description: CNN's Richard Quest explains why Cyprus' banking sector is unlike any other in the region.

item.title: Argentina a complex crucible for pope
item.description: Does it matter that the new pope comes from Argentina? It matters greatly, because Argentina shaped the life and the views of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, now Pope Francis. Through Francis, Argentina will help shape the church.

item.title: Can pope change church?
item.description: Father Joseph McShane tells CNN's Christiane Amanpour whether Pope Francis has the background to reform

item.title: Why women are less free after Iraq War
item.description: Iraqi women may have obtained some benefits since the war began in 2003 but women's rights campaigner Zainab Salbi says they have lost far more than they have gained.

item.title: Did Iraq War give birth to Arab Spring?
item.description: I was living in Syria when the statues of Saddam Hussein in neighboring Iraq came toppling down.

item.title: Why Obama's trip to Israel matters
item.description: This week, Barack Obama will embark on his first trip to Israel as president. The visit will enable him to engage, experience and touch Israelis in ways that move and bolster us.

item.title: Sudan must end 'cruel' amputation
item.description: Sudan's Deputy Chief Justice recently made the alarming announcement that his government might start training judges to cut off the hands and legs of convicted criminals, if doctors refuse to carry out amputations as punishment.

item.title: Syria: Chemical war fears grow after missile attack
item.description: The specter of chemical weapons attacks in the Syrian civil war is growing, with the government and rebels each blaming the other side for using such munitions.

item.title: Syria accused of hitting Lebanon
item.description: Syria is accused of using jets to fire rockets into Lebanon. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry says the U.S. will not stand in the way of its allies arming the rebels.

item.title: Syrian rebel leader: Defect, or else
item.description: Syrian rebel general calls on Assad's soldiers to defect... 'or we will track you down.'

item.title: Syria's first lady visits opera
item.description: The controversial wife of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad made a rare public appearance over the weekend at the Damascus Opera House.

item.title: Rape-fear tourist jumped from balcony
item.description: A British woman touring India leaped from the balcony of her hotel room to escape the hotel's owner, who had been trying to enter her room and was arrested on suspicion of trying to rape her, police said Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. flies B-52s over South Korea
item.description: The U.S. Air Force is breaking out some of its heaviest hardware to send a message to North Korea.

item.title: Iraq bombs kill 48 on war anniversary
item.description: Car bombs and roadside explosions killed at least 18 people within a one-hour period in and around Baghdad on Tuesday, authorities said.

item.title: Contractors reap $138B from Iraq war
item.description: Eight days after the invasion of Iraq on March 19 2003, Paul Wolfowitz, then deputy defence secretary and a leading proponent of the war, told a Congressional committee: "We are dealing with a country that can really finance its own reconstruction, and relatively soon."

item.title: Pakistan arrest in Daniel Pearl murder
item.description: Pakistani officials say they have arrested a suspect in connection with the gruesome 2002 murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.

item.title: Soccer: Inter faces new race charge
item.description: Inter Milan has been hit with another racism charge after UEFA confirmed it has launched an investigation into allegations that the club's fans racially abused Tottenham players during last week's Europa League tie.

item.title: Dead adopted boy: Russia slams Texas
item.description: Russia's child rights ombudsman slammed Texas prosecutors for deciding not to charge the adoptive parents of a Russian boy who died suddenly in January, Russia's RIA Novosti news agency reported Tuesday.

item.title: American guilty in Tokyo hotel murder
item.description: A Japanese court on Tuesday found a 19-year-old American man guilty of murdering an Irish student in a Tokyo hotel room last year.

item.title: More U.S. military sue over Fukushima
item.description: Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) faces mounting damages from the 2011 Fukushima disaster as more U.S. servicemembers joined a lawsuit accusing the Japanese national utility of lying about the risks involved in an aid effort to the stricken area in 2011.

item.title: Police: Chicago baby killed by gunshot
item.description: A Chicago baby who was killed when someone fired on her father's minivan last week was shot once, not multiple times as previously reported, police said Monday at a press conference.

item.title: Italy, India at odds over Marines
item.description: A diplomatic showdown between Italy and India is escalating, with Rome saying that an Indian court order forbidding the Italian ambassador from leaving the South Asian country breaches international law.

item.title: Obama to Israel: Low expectations
item.description: As President Obama heads to Israel, there is no expectation of big breakthroughs and questions about his frosty relationship with Prime Minister Netanyahu.

item.title: Francis vows to protect 'all creation'
item.description: New Pope Francis celebrates Mass Francis presented with fisherman's ring Pope driven to Mass in open-top SUV Tens of thousands pack St. Peter's Square

item.title: Text of homily
item.description: Homily of the Holy Father at the Inauguration of his Papal Ministry

item.title: How to protect unpredictable pope
item.description: CNN's Ben Wedeman reports on security jitters surrounding the unpredictable, populist-prone Pope Francis.

item.title: 5 things to know about the new pope
item.description: From the Vatican to Buenos Aires, Catholics worldwide rejoiced when Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio became the new pope.

item.title: Humble pope has complicated past
item.description: Pope Francis is being painted as a humble and simple man, but his past is tinged with controversy surrounding topics as sensitive as gay marriage and political atrocities.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: When Travolta swept Diana off her feet
item.description: Sumptuous velvet, delicate sequins, intricate beading: They are dresses fit for a princess -- Princess Diana, that is -- and if you've got a big pocketbook (with a designer label, naturally), they could be yours.

item.title: iPhone: Big-screen rivals catching up
item.description: Almost three years ago Dell launched a phone called the Streak, an Android-based handset with a 5-inch display that was marketed more as a tablet with phone capabilities than the other way around.

item.title: 2011: Who really killed Daniel Pearl?
item.description: CNN's Brian Todd looks at a report with details on the killing of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.

item.title: Israelis watch the war next door
item.description: The sights and sounds of war across the border in Syria have Israelis on edge. CNN's Sara Sidner reports.

item.title: How cityscapes are changing
item.description: The Tokyo-based architect is changing the city landscapes around the world.

item.title: Medals for drone operators?
item.description: Ruben Navarrette says handing out medals to drone operators reinforces the fantasy of war as a video game.

item.title: Will South Korea join nuclear arms race?
item.description: Threats from North Korea have sparked talk of South Korea developing a nuclear deterrent.

item.title: Pollution: China's 'airpocalypse'
item.description: China sees it's worst pollution in a decade as thick smog sets in on Beijing heightening health concerns.

item.title: Damon: How Iraq has changed
item.description: It was an odd splash of color that jumped out from the drab gray shades of the dusty battleground in Iraq: a red shoe smaller than my hand, adorned with a pink ribbon and bow.

item.title: Rape 'every 22 minutes' in India
item.description: Another shocking sexual attack puts a spotlight on rapes in India, reports CNN's Sumnima Udas.

item.title: HIV: 'Functional cure' for some?
item.description: Evidence is mounting that it is possible to control the virus that causes AIDS with early treatment, so further therapy is not immediately needed.

item.title: Human race is 'essentially good'
item.description: Before I set out to travel this world, 12 years ago, I used to believe that the human race as a whole was basically a few steps above wolves.

item.title: Rembrandt self-portrait revealed
item.description: A mystery portrait donated to a British heritage charity has been identified as a work by Dutch master Rembrandt van Rijn -- worth more than $30 million.

item.title: Quest: Deposit tax punishes Cypriots
item.description: Never underestimate the capacity of the Eurozone to shoot itself in both feet, writes CNN's Richard Quest.

item.title: 5 epic helicopter prison escapes
item.description: The spectacular, airborne escape of two Canadian inmates Sunday stunned witnesses and showcased the illicit ingenuity behind one of the more creative prison breaks.

item.title: Clinton backs same-sex marriage
item.description: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton announced for the first time she supports marriage rights for same-sex couples.

item.title: Bullying blamed for child's death
item.description: Authorities in Mexico are investigating a case of what some are calling extreme bullying. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: First days show pope's humility
item.description: One expert says Jorge Bergoglio has already shown that as Pope Francis he will be the down-to-earth man people yearn for in a spiritual leader.

item.title: Is director Creevey next big thing?
item.description: After only his second movie, British director Eran Creevey is being hailed as the next big thing. Neil Curry reports.

item.title: Amputation verdicts slammed
item.description: Sudan's Deputy Chief Justice recently made the alarming announcement that his government might start training judges to cut off the hands and legs of convicted criminals, if doctors refuse to carry out amputations as punishment.

item.title: Iraq women 'lost out'
item.description: Iraqi women may have obtained some benefits since the 2003 war but rights campaigner Zainab Salbi says they have lost far more.

item.title: Iraq's booming oil future
item.description: Northern Iraqi oil fields and potential reserves in the region are being explored by small independent companies.

item.title: Envoy: Obama's strong Israel ties
item.description: Michael Oren says the president's trip to Israel, his first while in office, will demonstrate the strength of the connections between the two nations

item.title: Why media's failure on Iraq still stings
item.description: The 10th anniversary this month of the invasion of Iraq will remind most people of a divisive and dubious war that toppled Saddam Hussein but claimed the lives of nearly 4,500 Americans and more than 100,000 Iraqi civilians.

item.title: Did Iraq War make Arab Spring?
item.description: 10 years after the invasion of Iraq, Ed Husain explores whether the fall of Saddam Hussein inspired Arab revolutionaries across the region.

item.title: Sandberg: Believe in yourself
item.description: Sheryl Sandberg says institutional barriers hold women back, but they can improve the odds of success by believing in themselves and taking action

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Conventional wisdom had it that Xi would be a weak leader because he had not been hand-picked by Deng Xiaoping. How wrong was that?

item.title: Iraq War: Courage amid the carnage
item.description: Ten years on, the war has left a heavy toll on Iraqis who had no say. CNN's Arwa Damon reports everything that every resident knew to be normal was crushed, tearing down the very fabric of society.

item.title: New pope makes a buzz with Catholics
item.description: CNN's Ben Wedeman looks at how the personable character of Pope Francis is energizing Catholics around the world.

item.title: Earliest ever cherry blossoms in Tokyo
item.description: Japan's prettiest national pastime of hanami, or cherry blossom viewing, has got off to its earliest start ever.

item.title: Bono: Enter 'factivist'
item.description: Bono says if the current trajectory can hold, extreme poverty could be eliminated by 2030

item.title: How I stood up to al Qaeda in war
item.description: CNN's Arwa Damon revisits Mohammed, a man who stood up to al Qaeda during the Iraq war.

item.title: Fairy tale of Swedish princess
item.description: A Swedish princess is laid to rest after living a fairy tale love story. CNN's Max Foster reports.

item.title: In digital age, recall beauty of paper
item.description: Bob Greene says as even as we embrace the wonders of online media in a digital age, it's worth appreciating the tactile, comforting, here-when-you-want-me world of words and pictures on paper

item.title: 300 days with Cirque du Soleil
item.description: On the road for 300 days a year, a Cirque du Soleil touring troupe of 175 relies on the same precise planning for its travel arrangements as it does for its acrobatic moves and dare devil routines.

item.title: Tribe marries same-sex couple
item.description: Gene Barfield and his partner, Tim LaCroix, celebrated their 30th anniversary by getting married.

item.title: Pope Francis cracks up cardinals
item.description: "I hope you haven't made a mistake," Pope Francis told the cardinals at his celebratory dinner after he was chosen to lead the Catholic Church. He then urged the assembled hierarchy to nourish their bodies, and said with a grin, "May God forgive you for what you've done."

item.title: Man gets airport flash mob surprise
item.description: An Oklahoma City man received a surprise proposal from his girlfriend after a two-year mission trip.

item.title: One-handed violinist
item.description: Adrian Anantawan prefers to be judged for what people hear, not what they see. What they'd see is a one-handed violinist.

item.title: Photos: Francis dons symbols of papal power
item.description: See the best images from the day's events as thousands crowd St. Peter's Square to see Francis begin his papacy.

item.title: Pope's sister prayed: Not him!
item.description: Maria Elena Bergoglio was in her home in Argentina when she heard the shocking news: Jorge Mario Bergoglio -- her brother -- was the new pope.

item.title: Did Bush, Blair commit war crimes?
item.description: OPINION: A decade ago, lawyer Michael Mansfield led the Legal Action Against War protest group. Today, he says George Bush and Tony Blair should be tried for war crimes over their roles in Iraq.

item.title: Opinion: Why the Iraq War was for oil
item.description: CNN Exclusive: Antonia Juhasz, author of "The Bush Agenda," says Big Oil were the winners of the Iraq War -- and that the plans to open up Iraq's oil fields were designed years before the invasion.

item.title: Open Mic: How life changed for Iraqis
item.description: Iraqis step up to CNN's Open Mic and share what their lives are like 10 years after the U.S. invasion of their country.

item.title: Iraq newsmakers: Where are they now?
item.description: Ten years ago this week, President George W. Bush announced that the United States and coalition forces had begun military action against Iraq.

item.title: Hans Blix: Iraq war a 'terrible mistake'
item.description: CNN exclusive: Hans Blix, the former lead weapons inspector in Iraq, recounts the lead-up to the war -- and worries history could repeat itself.

item.title: Francis' inauguration
item.description: Mass takes place for pope's inauguration Francis presented with fisherman's ring Pope driven to Mass in open-top SUV Up to 200,000 people in St. Peter's Square

item.title: Hans Blix
item.description: CNN exclusive: Hans Blix, the former lead weapons inspector in Iraq, recounts conversations he had with Tony Blair and Condoleezza Rice in the lead-up to the war -- and worries history could repeat itself.

item.title: Epic copter escapes
item.description: The spectacular, airborne escape of two Canadian inmates Sunday stunned witnesses and showcased the illicit ingenuity behind one of the more creative prison breaks.

item.title: Rembrandt revealed
item.description: A mystery portrait donated to a British heritage charity has been identified as a work by Dutch master Rembrandt van Rijn -- worth more than $30 million.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps geothermal potential
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: Sri Lanka's mass elephant migration
item.description: Poachers have decimated elephant populations across Africa and parts of Asia, killing thousands of animals for their revered ivory.

item.title: Xi: China's new boss in a hurry
item.description: Xi Jinping has taken the center stage as China's undisputed paramount leader.

item.title: Li Keqiang named Chinese premier
item.description: Li Keqiang on Friday was named China's premier, the No. 2 position in the Chinese government, completing the once-a-decade transition of leadership in the world's most populous nation.

item.title: Chinese farm claims dead pigs
item.description: A Chinese farm admitted to dumping dead pigs into Huangpu River, which had about 6,000 bloated carcasses pulled from its water this week, state media reported.

item.title: Will China finally 'bite' North Korea?
item.description: North Korea, China's longtime ally, has vexed Beijing for years with its rocket launches, nuclear tests, kidnapping of Chinese fishermen and other erratic behavior. Yet, Beijing has run interference at the United Nations to temper punishments against Pyongyang, and has even helped Pyongyang circumvent sanctions.

item.title: Coca-Cola probed over mapping
item.description: The government of a remote province in western China says it is investigating Coca-Cola over allegations that it illegally mapped parts of the province, as China and the US engage in an escalating war of words over cyber espionage.

item.title: Inflation warning from central bank
item.description: China must be "on high alert" against inflation, central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan said on Wednesday, striking a hawkish tone at his most important news conference of the year.

item.title: Artist Ai Weiwei to release album
item.description: Dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, whose artwork is shown in museums around the world, is taking a different direction with his latest project -- a heavy metal album.

item.title: World's biggest mall a 'ghost town'
item.description: They built it, but the shoppers didn't come.

item.title: Report: Chinese military hacking
item.description: The Chinese government is sponsoring cyber-espionage to attack top U.S. companies, according to Grady Summers, vice president of security firm Mandiant.
